title: String Quartet (Chausson)
text:
The String Quartet in C minor, <a href="opus%20number">Op.</a> 35, was begun by <a href="Ernest%20Chausson">Ernest Chausson</a> in 1898 and the composer had fully scored all but part of the third and last <a href="movement%20%28music%29">movement</a> before he died in a bicycle accident on 10 June 1899. He was engaged on writing the last movement on the very day of his fatal accident.
Relying on the drafts left behind by Chausson, <a href="Vincent%20d%27Indy">Vincent d'Indy</a> completed the final movement at the request of the composer's family. The <a href="string%20quartet">string quartet</a> was premiered on 27 January <a href="1900%20in%20music">1900</a>, at the Société Nationale de Musique (SNM). The performers were Armand Parent, Lammers, Denoyers and Baretti.
The work is believed to be influenced by the <a href="impressionism">impressionism</a> of <a href="Claude%20Debussy">Debussy</a> and the first movement quotes his <a href="String%20Quartet%20%28Debussy%29">string quartet op. 10</a>, while the second adopts the Tarnhelm theme from <a href="Richard%20Wagner">Wagner</a>'s <a href="opera">opera</a> "<a href="Das%20Rheingold">Das Rheingold</a>".
The three movements are:
